STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 24, 2023
Kevin Darrell Mitchell
WASHTENAW COUNTY YOUTH CENTER
4125 WASHTENAW AVE,
ANN ARBOR, MI, 48108-1003
Re: License #: CE810254752
Dear Mr. Mitchell:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/6/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan
is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Tracey Ventola, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
R400.4113 Employee records.
Rule 113. An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.
Two of sixteen files were missing three dated references which are obtained prior to the
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which are less than 12 months
old. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 4/28/22 and CAP, signed 5/4/22, and Interim
Report, 07/01/21, and CAP, signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous
plan failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R400.4113 Employee records.
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the
institution shall complete a written evaluation of the
convictions that addresses the nature of the conviction,
the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity for the
purpose of determining suitability for employment in the
institution.
Two of sixteen employee files had an employee with criminal convictions and no written
evaluation was completed.
R400.4113 Employee records.
(h) A statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
Two of sixteen employee records did not include a statement from the employee regarding
their criminal conviction.
3

R400.4113 Employee records.
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency,
Canadian province, or other country where the
person usually resides or has resided in the
previous 5 years.
Three of sixteen employee files did not contain documentation that the employee has not
been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 4/28/22 and CAP, signed 5/4/22, and Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP,
signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed and how they are
going to ensure compliance.
R400.4113 Employee records.
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s performance
annually thereafter.
Five of sixteen employee files were missing a written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within 180
days. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 4/28/22 and CAP, signed 5/4/22. The facility
must identify why the previous plan failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed for each
resident within 24 hours of admission to a facility.
Two of three files were missing the initial health screen.
R400.4147 Dental care.
(2) A dental examination within 12 months prior to
admission shall be documented for there shall be an
examination not later than 90 calendar days following
admission.
Two of three files reviewed found the youth did not have a dental exam within 12 months
prior to admission or within 90 days after admission.
4

R400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in
the resident’s case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident’s preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at
the time of admission.
Two of three files reviewed did not document the youth’s preparation for placement and
general physical and emotional state at admission. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report, 4/28/22, and CAP, signed 5/4/22, and Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP, signed
07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed and how they are going to
ensure compliance.
R400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and every 15
calendar days thereafter, an institution shall complete a
written service plan. The service plan shall include all of
the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons those needs are
unmet.
One of three files reviewed did not have an initial service plan completed within 30 days
of admission. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 4/28/22, and CAP, signed 5/4/22,
and Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP, signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the
previous plan failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
restraints; elimination of restraints.
(2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
(e) Restraining youth in a prone position or any restraint
that restricts the youth’s airway.
One of three restraint reports reviewed, noted that a youth was restrained prone on the
bed to place hand cuffs and shackles on the youth.
5

R400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
restraints; elimination of restraints.
(5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in
a manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to
the severity of the youth’s behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition,
medical condition, psychiatric condition, and personal
history, including any history of trauma, and must be
done in a manner consistent with the youth’s treatment
plan.
Two of three restraint reports reviewed documented that the youth were not restrained in
a manner that was safe. One youth was restrained prone, and the other youth was
restrained by one person with a hug move which is not provided for in their restraint model.
R400.4161 Secure juvenile justice facilities, mechanical restraint; policies and
procedures; prohibitions.
(3) The only mechanical restraints that staff may use
within a facility are handcuffs, unless circumstances
require, and written approval is given by the chief
administrator, for the use of leg shackles, a leg bar, or
belly chains or belly belts, or both.
One of three restraint reports reviewed found a youth was placed in shackles without
written approval by the chief administrator.
R400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities; seclusion plan;
prohibitions; reduction and elimination.
(7) During the time that a youth is in seclusion, staff must
perform variable interval, eye on checks of youth. The
time between the variable interval checks must not
exceed 15 minutes unless the situation requires
continuous observation for the child's safety, including, but
not limited to, youth exhibiting suicidal ideations or
performing self-harm.
Two of two seclusion reports reviewed found that variable interval checks were not done.
6

R400.4163 Health status assessment; notification; debriefing; reporting.
(5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form
prescribed by the department for each incident involving
the use of seclusion or restraint. The initial report shall
be submitted to the department within 24 hours of the
incident occurring. A final incident report shall be
submitted no later than 72 hours after the incident has
occurred.
Three of three restraint reports and two of two seclusion reports were not submitted to the
department.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Training documentation was missing signature dates. Please make sure to sign
off and date the training document.
• Performance evaluations were missing signature dates which makes it impossible
to know what date the evaluation was completed with the employee.
• Job descriptions are provided to staff, but they are not signed by the employee. It
is recommended that when an employee accepts a job that they sign their job
description documenting they received it and are aware of their job requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was provided consultation related to clearances for volunteers.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during this
period under review.
Financial Overview
The facility's financial plan was reviewed and showed no concerns.
7

PREA compliance (if applicable)
The facility appears to be in compliance with PREA.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator’s assessment was reviewed noting 2022 was a challenging
year with continued staffing shortages, increased census, and pandemic related
sickness with staff, and family of staff. Monitoring CAP from previous year was
considered with new protocols but the main focus was on providing excellent care
to youth.
Staff and Youth Interviews
All staff interviewed said they enjoy working at Washtenaw County Youth Center.
They reported feeling supported and having access to their supervisors. Staff
reported they have good leadership and like that the focus at the facility is on
developing deep relationships with the youth they work with and not placing hands
on unless absolutely necessary.
Youth reported the facility treats them well and that they feel safe. All youth
reported they have adequate hygiene products, bedding, and that the food is pretty
good.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was clean, neat and well organized. I viewed the staff offices, the
wings, youth rooms, the milieu area and the kitchen. The meal menus were posted
in the kitchen.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
_____________________________________
Tracey Ventola Date 4/20/23
Licensing Consultant
8

Approved By:
